titleStmt.title: Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part II).
titleStmt.author: David Livingstone

bibl.title: Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part II).
bibl.author: David Livingstone

div.p:
XXI 115 119
The men utter similar salutations
and Sekeletu recievesreceives all
with becoming indifference
After a few minutes con-
-versation and telling the news
the headman of the village
who is almost always a
Makololo would rises and
brings forth a number of
of large pots of beer - PCalabashes
^ being used as cups ^ for drinking are also handed
round and as many as can
partake of the beverage -^ do soThey
grasping these thingsvessels so eagerly
that they are in danger of being
broken -

They bring forth also large
pots orand bowls of ^ thick milk = some
contain 6 or 8 gallons and
each of these isas pwell as of
the beer, is given into a particular
person who has the power to
divide it to ^ with whom he will - The head man
of any section
of the tribe is
generally selected
for this office -
The milk is eaten with the
hand - Spoons not being
generally in fashion - I often
presented my friends with
iron spoons and it was
curious to observe how they
habit of the hand eating pre-
-vailed though they were delighted
with the spoons They lifted
out a little with the utensil
then put it on the left hand
and eatate it thence out of that

As the MakoloMakololo have great abundance
of cattle and the chief is expected
to feed all who accompany
him he either selects an ox
or two of his own from the
numerous cattle stations ^ that he
possesses at different spots
all over the country or is
presented by the headmen
of the villages he visits with
as many as he needs by
way of tribute - The animals are killed
by a thrust
from a
small Javelin
in the region
of the heart
the wound
being purposely
small in
order to avoid
any loss of
blood - This
and which, with
are immediately slaughtered
in a manner which saves
all the blood - a small a stab
in the region of the heart being
their usual mode of proceeding
killing oxen - Thise blood with
the internal parts belong are the
persequisitesperquisites of the men who
perform the work of the butcher
hence all are eager to render
service in that line -
Each tribe has its own way
of cutting up ^ & distributing an animal - Among
the Makololo the hump and
ribs belong to the chief - Among
the Bakuena the breast is
his persequisite - After the oxen
are cut up the different joints
are placed before Sekeletu,
and he apportions them
among the gentlemen of the
party - The whole is rapidly
divided by their attendants, cut
117 121 3
into long strips and so many ^ of these are thrown
into the fires at once ^ that they are
nearly put out - Half broiled &
burning hot ^ the meatit is quickly handed
round Everyone gets a mouthful
but no one except the chief
has time to masticate - It is
not the enjoyment of eating they
aim at wish but the pleasure of having
^ got as much of the food safe in the stomach as
possible during the short
time the others are cramming
as well as themselves - ^ for No no
one can eat more than a
mouthful after the others have
finished - They are eminently
gregarious in their eating -
and as they despise any one
who eats alone I always poured
out two cups of coffee at my
own meals - so that the chief
or some one of the principal
men might partake as well
as myself - Of coffee they
all soon become very fond
and indeed some of the tribes
X attribute the greater fecundity to the
daily use of this beverage - They
were all well acquainted with
>the sugar cane as they cultivate
it a in the Barotse country
but knew nothing of the
method of extracting the sugar
from it - They use it ^ the cane by
- only in chewing ^ it alone - Sekeletu
118 122
relishing the sweet coffee and
biscuits I then had - said "he knew
my heart loved him by finding his
own hearted warming to my
food - " He had been visited
during my absence at the Cape by some
traders and Griquas and
"their coffee did not taste half
so nice as mine - because they
loved his ivory only and not
himself - " It is This was ^ certainly an
original mode of discerning
character

Sekeletu and I had each
a little gipseygypsy tent in which to
sleep - Their Makololo huts are generally
clean - ^ while those of the Makalaka
are generally infested with vermin
The cleanliness of the former
is owing to the habit of frequently
smearing the floors with
a plaisster of composed of
cowdung and earth - InIn so some
villages where ^ is if we slept
in the tent the mice ran
over theour faces and disturbed
theour sleep or hungry prowling
dogs - would eat one'sour shoes
all off except the soles - or
were guilty of other misdemeanours
In these cases Wewe got the loan of a hut.
The best sort of Makololo
huts consist of three circular
walls - with small holes similar
119 123
to thoseat in a dog house as doors
and one has to bend down the
body to get in even when on
all fours - The roof is formed
of reeds or straight sticks in
shape like a chinaman'sChinaman's hat
and bound firmly together with
circular bands which are
lashed with the strong inner
bark of the mimosa trees -
When prepared all except the
thatch it is lifted on to the circular
walls the rim resting on a circle of poles
between each of which the
third wall is built - As theThe
roof is thatched with fine grass
& soewned with the same material
as the lashings and as it
porojects far beyond the walls
and reaches within four
feet of the ground the shade
is the best to be found in
the country - They ^ These huts are very
cool in the hottest day
but are close and want deficient
in ventilation by night -

The bed is a mat made
of rushes sewedn together with
twine - The hip bone soon
becomes sore on the hard floor
flat surface surface as we cannot
make a hole in the floor
as we do when sleeping on
grass or sand to recievereceive
the prominent part called Trochanter
120 6124
by anatomists

Our course at this time led
us to part above Sesheke
called Katonga where ^ there is a village
belonging to a Bashubia man
named Sekhosi exists - The
X river is here LatLatitude 17° 29' 26" LongLongitude - 24° 33'
The river here is somewhat
broader than at Sesheke and
certainly not less than 600 ydsyards
It flows somewhat slowly
in the first part of its Eastern
course - When the canoes
came from Sekhosi to take
us over one of the comrades
of Sebituane rose and looking
to Sekeletu called out "The
elders of a host always take
the lead in an attack" This
was understood at once and
Sekeletu with all the young
men were obliged to give the
elders the precedence and
remain on the southern bank
and see that all went orderly
into the canoes - It took a
considerable time to ferry over
the whole of our large party
as even with quick paddling
from six to eight minutes
were spent in the mere
passage from bank to bank
121 125
Several days were nowhere
spent in collecting canoes
from different villages on
the river which we nowhere
learned is called by the whole
of the Barotse the Liambai
or Leeambye - The term Sesheke
means white sand banks
many of which exist near
the town of that name -
There is Anotheranother ^ village called Sesheke exists in
the valley of the Barotse is and
for a similar reason
But the term Liambai
means "the large river" or
the river par excellence -
Luambeji Luambesi --
Ambezi - Ojimbesi & Zambesi &c - all
possess a similar signification
and express the native
idea of this magnificent
stream being the main
drain of the country -

In order to assist in
the support of our large
party and ^ at the same time to ^ see the addjacentadjacent
country I went several times
during our stay to the lan
North of the village for game
The country is covered with
clumps of beautiful trees
among which fine open
glades stretch away in every
direction - These when the
122 126
the river is in flood are
inundated but the tree
covered elevated spots are
much more numerous
here than in the country
south of the Leeambye -
The soil as it is everywhere
on spots reached by the
inundattioninundation is dark loam
while among the trees it
is sandy, and not covered
so densely with grass as
Elsewhereelsewhere the other A trees covered with
A sandy ridge on the running
parallel to, and about eight
miles from the river is
the limit of the inundation
on the North - There are large
ptracts of this sandy forest
in that direction till you
come to other large districts
of alluvial soil and fewer
trees - The latter ^ soil is always
found in the vicinity of rivers
which either now overflow
their banks annually or
formerly did so - The
people enjoy rain in sufficient
quantity to raise very
large supplies of grain
and earth-nuts -

This district contains
great quantities of a small
antelope named Thianyane
123 127
unknown in the South - It stands
about 18 inches high - is very
graceful in its movements
and utters a cry of alarm
not unlike that of the
domestic fowl - It is of a
brownish red colour on the
sides and back - with the
belly & lower part of the tail
white - It is very timid
but the maternal affection
that the little thing bears to its
young will ^ often induce it make even
it to offer battle to a man
approaching its youngthem -
When the young are too tender
to run about with the dam
she puts one foot on the
prominence about the seventh
cervical vertebra or withers
The instinct of the young
enables it to understand
that it is now required to
kneel down and ^ to remain
quite still till it hears the
bleating of its dam - If you
see an otherwise gregarious
she antelope separated from
the herd and going alone to
someany where you may be
sure she has laid her
little one to sleep some where
in some cozy spot - The
colour of the hair in the
124 128
young is better adapted for shading
in with the ground than
than that of the when it becomes older ^ animals and
does not need to be screened
from the observation of
birds beasts of prey - I observed Thethe Arabs at [Aden
in order when to makeing their camels
kneel down press the thumb
on the withers of their camels
in exactly the same way
the antelopes do with their
young - And probably they have
been led to the custom by
seeing the same plan adopted
141 by the gazelle of the Desert

Great numbers of
buffaloes - zebras - Tsessebes
Tagetsi and Eland or Pohu
graized undisturbed on these
plains so ^ that very little exertion
was required forto securinge
a pretty fair supply for
the party during the necessary
delay. Hunting on foot
as all whatever those who have
engaged in it in this country
will at once
concedeadmit ^ may think, is very hard
work indeed - The heat of
the sun by day is ^ so great
even in winter as it
now was, that had there been
any one on whom I could
have thrown the task
he would have been most
125 129
welcome to all the sport the
toil could impart But the
Makololo shot so badly ^ that I was
obliged in order to save my
powder to go myself -

We gotshot a beautiful cow
Eland standing in the shade
of a fine tree - ^ It was evident that Sheshe had lately
had got her calf killed by a lion
for there were five long
deep scratches on both
sides of her hind quarters as
if she had ranrun to the
rescue of her calf and the
lion leaving it had attacked
herself but was unable
to pull her down - When
lying on the ground the
milk running from her
fine large udder shewedshowed that
her she must have been
d seeking the shade from
the distress its non-removal
in the natural manner
caused - She was a beautiful
creature and Lebeole a Makololo
who accompanied
me speaking
in reference to its greater
size and beauty to cows
said "Jesus ought to have
given us these instead
of cattle - " It was a new
undescribed variety of this splendid
antelope - ^ It was marked with narrow
^ (omitted) white bands accross the ^
126 130
exactly like those of the Khoodoo
and havinghad a broad black
patch of more than a
hand breadth on the outer
side of the forearm - which
imparts the idea when
theirre are hundreds of them
omit together of a regiment -
with their knee pans on -

Having at last procured
a sufficient number of canoes
we began to ascend the river
I had the choice of the whole and
selected the best which was 34 ft.feet
long by 20 inches wide - I had six
paddlers and Sekeletu ten - They
stand and keep the stroke with
great precision though they
change from side to side as
the course demands The men
at the head and stern are selected
from the strongest and most
expert of the whole - The canoes
being flat bottomed they can
go into very shallow water
and whenever the men can
feel the bottom they use the
paddles which are about
8 feet long as poles to punt
with - Our fleet consisted
of 16033 mencanoes and about
160 men - It was beautiful
to see them skimming along ^ so quickly and
127 131
and keeping the time so well
On land they ^vMakalaka fear the Makololo
On water the Makololo fear them
and cannot prevent them
from racing andwith each other
anddand - dashing along at the top of
their speed to the imminent
danger of over-turning their
placingplacing their mastersmasters' lives in
danger for in the event of
a capsize many of the Makololo
would sink ^ like as astones -
A case of this kind happened
on the first day of our voyage
up - The wind blowing generally
from the East raises very
large waves on the Leeambye
An old doctor of the Makololo
had his canoe filled by
one of these ^ waves and being
unable to swim was lost
The Barotse who were in
the canoe with him saved
themselves their clothing by swimming
and were afraid of being
punished with death in the
evening for not saving the
mandoctor as well - Had ^ he the
doctor been a man of more
influence this would have
been the case -

We proceeded rapidly up
the river and felt the pleasure
of looking on lands which
128 132
which had never been seen
by an European before - The
river is indeed a magnificent
one - often more than a mile
broad and adorned with many
islands of from three to five
miles long in length - - Both
islands and banks are covered
with forest and most of the
trees on the bank of the water
send down roots from their
branches like the Banian or
Ficus Indica The islands at a
little distance seem great rounded
masses of sylvan vegetation
reclining on the bosom of
the glorious stream - The beauty
of the scenery of some of the islands
is greatly increased by the
date palms with its gracefully
covered fronds and refreshing
light green colour near the
bottom of the picture and the
lofty palmyra towering far
above and casting its feathery
foliage against a cloudless
sky - It being winter we
had the strange colouring
on the banks which many
parts of the African landscape
assumes - The country adjacent
to the river is rocky and
undulating abounding in Elephants
and all the other large game
except Leches and Nakongs
129 133
which seem generally to avoid
stony ground - The soil is of
a reddish colour and very
fertile as is attested by the
great quantities of grain raised
annually by the Banyeti
A great many villages of
this poor and very industrious
people are situated on both
banks of the river - They are
expert hunters of the hippo^potami
and other animals and very
proficient in the manufacturymanufacture
of articles of wood & iron
The whole of this part of the
country being infested with the
Tsetse they are unable to
rear domestic animals - This
may have led to their skill in
manufacture handicraft works
Some make large wooden
vessels with very neat lids
or wooden bowels of all sizes
and since the Makololo
idea of sitting on stools has
entered the Makololo mind
Theythey have shewnshown great taste
in the different forms
given ^ to the legs of theirse pieces
of furniture -

Other Banyeti or Manyeti
as they are called make
neat and strong baskets of
the split roots of a certain
tree while others excel in
130 134
pottery and iron - I cannot find
that they have ever been
warlike Indeed the wars
in the centre of the country
where no slave trade existed
have seldom ever been about
anything else but cattle
So well known is this
that several tribes refuse to
keep cattle because they
tempt their enemies to come
and steal - And this though
they have no objection to
eat them when offered to them
and their country admits
of being well stocked - I have
heard of one war having
occurred from another
cause - Three brothers
Barolongs fought for the
possession of a woman
and the tribe has remained
permanently divided ever since

From the bend up to
the North called Katima-moleloKatima Mulilo
(I quenched fire) the bed of the
river is rocky and the
stream rapid - These rapids
forming a succession of
rapids and cataracts which
prevent continuous
navigation are dangerous when the
river is low - The rapids
are not visible when the
river is full but the
131 135
cataracts of Nambuee - Bombue
and Kale must always be
dangerous - ^ When the river
is low Thethe fall seen when
at low water at each
of these is between four and
six feet - But the falls of
Goynye present a much more
serious obstacle - There we
were obliged to take the canoes
out of the water and carry
them more than a mile by
land - The fall is about
forty feet - The main body of
water which comes over
thise ledge of rock is when the
river is low is collected
into a space 70 or 80 ydsyards wide
before it takes the leap - And
a mass of rock being thrust
forward against the roaring
torrent a loud sound is
produced - Tradition reports
in this place the destruction
of two hippopotamus hunters
who too eager in the pursuit
of their pursuit of a wounded
animal were with their
intended prey drawn down
into the frightful gulphgulf - There
is also thea tradition of a
man evidently of superior
mind who left the Barotse
his own countrymen and
came down the river, took
132 136
advantage of the falls and led
out a portion of water
there for irrigation - Such minds
must have arisen from time
to time in these regions as
well as in our own country
but ignorant of the use of letters
they have left no memorial
behind them - We dug out
some of an inferior kind
of yam from his
garden but one never expects
to find a grave nor a stone
of remembrance set up in
South Africa The very
rocks are illiterate - they
contain so few fossils
Those here are of hardened
sandstone with madrepore
holes in it - It covers a
great part of the bottom
of the valley, and is often
covered with 12 or 15 feet of soft calcareous
tufa - At Bombue we
have the ^ same porphoriticporphyritic trap
which appears at the confluence
of the Chobe faurther down

As we passed up the
river the different villages of
Banyeti turned out to
present Sekeletu with food
and skins as their tribute
One large village is placed
at Gonye to whose dues
133 137
are to assist the Makololo to carry
their canoes past the falls -
The Tsetse lighted on us even
in the middle of the stream
This we crossed repeatedly in
order to make short cuts
at bends of the river - The
course is however remarkably
straight among the rocks
and at this period ^ point the river was
shallow on account of
the great breadth of surface
which it covers - When
we came to about 16° 16' South
Latitude the high ^ wooded banks
seemed to leave the river
and no more Tsetse appeared
Viewed from the flat reedy
basin in which it ^ the river now
flowed the banks seemed
prolonged into ridges of the
same wooded character
200 or 300 feet high and
stretching away to the N- N- E-North North East
and N- N- W-North North West untilluntil they
were twenty or thirty miles
apart - The intervening
space nearly one hundred
miles in length with the
Leeambye
winding gently
near the
middle is the true
Barotse valley - It bears
as I have since seen a
close resemblance to the
valley of the Nile and is
inundated annually but by the
Leambye and not by rains
134 138
exactly as Lower Egypt is
flooded by the Nile The
villages of the Barotse are
built on mounds some of
which are said to have
been raised artificially by
Santuru a former chief of
the Barotse and during
the inundation the whole
valley assumes the appearance
of an immense large lake
with the villages on the
mounds as islands just
as occurs in Egypt with
villages of the Egyptians
Some portion of this waters
of inundation comes from
the N- WNorth West werewhere great floodings
also occur but more ^ comes from
the North and North East
along the bed of the Leambye
itself - There are but few
trees in this in this valley
those which stand on the
mounds were nearly all
transplanted by Santuru for
shade The soil is extremely fertile
and the people never want
for grain for by taking
advantage of the moisture
of the inundation they can
raise two crops a year
The Barotse are strongly
attached to this fertile valley
they say "there hunger is unknown"
135 139
There are so many things besides
corn which a man can
find ^ here for food ^ that it is no wonder
they desert from Linyanti to
return to this place

Thise great valley is not
put to a tithe of the use it
might be - It is covered with
coarse succulent grasses
which afford ^ ample pasturage for
large herds of cattle - These
thrive wonderfully and give
milk copiously to their owners
When flooded, the cattle must
are compelled to leave it, the valley is and go to
the higher lands where they
fall off - Their return is a
time of joy -

It is impossible to say
whether this valley which
contains so much moisture
would raise corn as the
valley of the Nile does - It is
probably too much and would
make corn run entirely to
straw for one species of
grass was observed twelve
feet high and ^ the stem as thick as
as a man's thumb - At present
the pasturage is never eaten
off though the Makololo
possess very large herds of
cattle - ⎡There are no large
towns - The mounds on which
the towns and villages are
136 140
built being all small and the
people require to live apart
on account of their cattle

This visit was the first
Sekeletu had made ^ to these parts since he
attained the chieftainship - Those
who had taken part with
Mpepe were ^ consequently in ^ great terror - When
we came to the town of Mpepe's
father as he and another man
had counselled Mamochisane
to put Sekeletu to death and
marry Mpepe, the two were
led forth and tossed into
the river - Nokuane was the
one of the executioners [again
145 When I remonstrated against
human blood being shed in the
off hand way ^ in which they were
proceeding the counsellors
justified their acts by the
evidence given by Mamochisane
and calmly added "you see
we are still Boers, we are
not yet taught" -

Mpepe had given full
permission to the Mambari
slave dealers to trade in all
the Batoka and Bashukulompo
villages to the East of this -
He had given them both cattle
ivory and children and had
recievedreceived in return a large
blunderbuss to be mounted as a
cannon
137 141
When the slight circumstance
of my having coveringed the body of
the chief with my own
deranged the whole conspiracy
the Mambari in their stockade
were placed in very ackwardawkward
circumstances - It was
proposed to attack them and
drive them out of the country
at once but dreading a
commencement of hostilities
I urged the difficulties of such
a course and shewedshowed
that a stockade defended by
perhaps forty muskets would be
a serious affair - "Hunger is
strong enough for that" said
an underchief "a very great
fellow he is - " They thought
of attacking
them by
starvation As the chief
sufferers in case of such
an attack would have been
the poor slaves chained in
gangs - I interceded for them
and as the result of an
intercession of which they
were ignorant ^ was that they were
allowed to depart in peace

Nariele the capital of
the Barotse is built on a
mound which was con-
structed artificially - by Santuru
and was his store house
for grain - His own capital
stood about 500 yards to
the south of that in what
138 142
is now the bed of the river - All that
remains of the largest
mound in the valley is are
a few so cubic yards of
earth - to erect which
it cost the whole of the
people of Santuru the labour
of many years - As theThe same
thing has happened to another
ancient site of a town - Linangelo,
also on the left bank.
It would seem that Thethe river in this part of the
valley seems to bemust be wearing
Eastwards - No great rise
of the river is required
to submerge the whole valley
A rise of Tenten feet above the present
low water mark would
reach ^ ^the highest point
of the valley its greatest height as
seen in the markings of
the bank ofin in which stood
SanturusSanturu's ancient capital
and two or three feet more
would deluge all the villages
in the valley - This never
happens though it ^ the water sometimes comes
so near the foundations
of the huts ^ that the people cannot
move outside the walls of
reeds which encircle their
villages - When the river
is compressed among the
high rocky banks near
Gonye it rises 60 feet
